conversation.content:
As a Masters degree student, YOu Have a project and the brief goes thus:


Component A is a team presentation of 25 minutes (with 5 minutes of questions).

As a group you will be required to create a PowerPoint presentation which will detail the planning and management issues of a global project.

1.Choose a project you know off or you are interested in provided it is global, whether completed or in progress, and make sure that you are able to gather the information that is necessary for your analysis;

2.There are two sets of slides in Blackboard > Learning Material > week 1. These slides give you directions how to use UWE resources to find a case project.

3.Use the tools as described below in section 3. Content below and participate in the workshops to practice each tool with your group.

The presentation will be live, and all group members will present ONE part of the Assignment for which they will be individually marked. Not all group members will get the same mark necessarily, it depends on the quality of their work and presentation in their own part. Group members who do not participate and contribute to the Assignment will have to re-sit as they will get 0. .

This assessment strategy is employed to produce the type of output required by professional project management practice that is developed by a typical project team; and to maximize learning opportunities with added values for students’ development and character building.

This assignment requires you to develop research skills and find information that is useful for the purpose of detecting organizational issues related to the global environment and construct a plan. You will have to work with University databases and search through a large volume of information from Professional associations.

If you have difficulty to choose a global project here are some choices:

SMART CITIES
EXAMPLES
https://www.apm.org.uk/blog/five-of-the-uk-s-most-exciting-smart-city-projects/
https://publications.iadb.org/en/international-case-studies-smart-cities-santander-spain

GLOBAL HEALTHCARE PROJECTS
EXAMPLES
https://www.bond.org.uk/news/2017/04/7-projects-improving-healthcare-around-the-world

GLOBAL MEDICAL AND BIOTECH RESEARCH PROJECTS
EXAMPLES
https://globalprojects.ucsf.edu/
https://www.nihr.ac.uk/explore-nihr/funding-programmes/global-health.htm
https://www.tendersinfo.com/healthcare-and-medical-pharma-projects.php
https://www.pharmaceuticalonline.com/doc/top-10-international-pharmaceutical-biotech-c-0001

GLOBAL HUMANITARIAN PROJECTS
EXAMPLES
https://borgenproject.org/5-top-humanitarian-aid-organizations/
https://www.humanitarianprojectsinc.com/

These are some examples, you can find global projects in most industries.

Please do not just use Apple, Google or Toyota or any of these famous large organizations because you cannot have access to information about their projects. Choose projects about which you can discover information.

I strongly suggest that you attend the workshops and be proactive in forming groups in week 1 and use the Direction files in the Learning Materials folders showing you case study books to select project case studies.








2.Presentation Content & Structure
The live team presentations should not exceed 30 minutes including Q&A and feedback from the tutor. This means that the presentation should be approximately 25 minutes maximum. In a team of 5 people this means that each person will have to present their contribution for 5 minutes.

It is the responsibility of the team to allocate the parts of the work amongst them.


Content

Your task is to present your analysis & plan of a global project. You will choose the project as described in the section above.

STRUCTURE OF THE PRESENTATION - PARTS:

INTRODUCTION: introduce your project and your team and each team member’s contribution you are going to have a slide where you will attach next to each part the name of the team member who worked at it and who will present it.

ANALYSIS PART 1. Evaluate the challenges regarding such a project using the dimensions model from Binder
Evaluate the impact of environmental factors on this project.
oCollect information about the project environment through industry & professional reports and company literature or case studies. You do not need to do primary research and collect information from the organization people.

PLAN PART 2: Recommend the most appropriate method for managing your project using the Global Project Management Framework from Binder. This part will focus on:
1.a risk assessment based on the Global Project Management Framework
2.explain how you will deal with the issues of: international and intercultural communications, global team structures, and collaborative relationships with other organizations in the particular project
3.The team and project manager roles & skillset [competency maps/leadership framework/Belbin roles]

PLAN PART 3: Construct a Project Plan with objectives, a phase plan and collaboration tools and collaboration techniques as advised by Binder
*Note: be careful that the type of plan you present is linked to the methodology you chose. For example, if you select a specific agile methodology your plan should be based on the type of iterations of this method.

References: reports from industry or from organization/firm, company material and information from reputable sources (case studies, professional magazines articles etc.) and the sources from the models you use to conduct analysis






3.Preparation for Assignment A (mandatory)

Students are advised to attend the workshops because the Assignment consists of the use of a series of tools, each tool belonging to a part of the Assignment. Please look at the table below to see which workshops correspond to which tools and which parts of the Assignment.


Workshops Section in Assignment A Tool to use Workshop Session
Find a project
Introduction Use the slides Session 1
Detect the challenges Part 1 The Radar Chart Session 2
Detect success factors Part 1 The PIP Session 3
Describe the team competencies needed Part 2 Competency map Session 4
Design the project manager role & leadership Part 2 leadership framework Session 5
Describe the teams’ behavioural roles Part 2 Belbin team roles Session 6
Choose the way your teams will be creative Part 2 Brainstorming Techniques Session 7
Describe the cultural differences and challenges in your project Part 2 Hofstede cultural scores Session 8
Explain how you qill uaw technologies to deal with challenges Part 3 Collaboration platforms Session 9
Design project plan for your presentation Part 3 Already known tools Session 10

In preparing for this assessment, teams will be able to undertake a series of formative exercises and gain feedback in response. Expectations concerning the presentation will be discussed in workshops, and teams will also be able to present ONE draft presentation plan for formative review on the final workshop on week 10.



Your part of the project is to do the sessions 7 & 8; that is, Choose the way your teams will be creative (Brainstorming Techniques) and Describe the cultural differences and challenges in your project (Hofstede cultural scores)




The chosen global project is below, with all the information available.:

Project Title:AI IN ACTION (HOW THE HONGKONG DEVELOPMENT BUREAU BUIL THE PSS —
AN EARLY - WARNING - SIGN SYSTEM FOR PUBLIC WORKS PROJECTS)



EXECUTIVE SUMMARY
Hong Kong has a large volume of construction works
currently taking place; this will increase further and faster
in the coming years.
Hong Kong’s projects typically come in 15% under
budget. However, ten per cent of local projects over-run
their budgets, with a total overspend of eight percent.
Some flagship projects have over-run their budgets and
completion dates, causing public embarrassment.
It is crucial to get these cost and schedule estimates under
control in order that the booming infrastructure environment in Hong Kong can flourish to its potential while
carefully monitoring costs and performance.
We investigated whether Artificial Intelligence (AI) can play
a part in accurately predicting these outcomes and identifying ahead of time when a project is going off track, allowing
early intervention.
The large volume of projects in Hong Kong needs to be monitored collectively, with a system that allows leaders to focus
their efforts on the projects most likely to fail. An automated
system simplifies this process, and in our studies was found
to be as accurate as the best-in-class human cost estimates.
High quality data is available in Hong Kong, and we studied a total of 2,700 years of combined construction activity
and HKD 450bn in construction spent to trial this innovative project management approach. We unexpectedly discovered, however, that the AI needs only a very small amount
of data in order to make good predictions.
WE BELIEVE THESE EARLY FINDINGS WILL
INFORM A NEW APPROACH TO PROJECT PERFORMANCE MONITORING AND LEAD THE WAY IN
CAPITAL WORKS PROJECTS INTERNATIONALLY



THE CHALLENGE
Hong Kong expects project spending to increase by 42% between
2021 and 2031. The expected annual expenditure will reach up to
HKD 325bn by 2031.
However, these projects are not without their problems.
To spot challenges early, the Project Strategy and Governance
Office established a system to support supervision and governance of projects by providing early-warning signals to senior
leaders of projects that are at risk.
Projects are used to deliver the
most significant initiatives in the world;
from the Olympics, the artificial island
of Lantau, to the International Space
Station.
One of the challenges currently
faced by project leaders and investors is
that projects do not perform well.
They underperform in terms
of execution, with significant cost and
schedule overruns. 50% delays are common.
Our research has shown this
woeful underperformance is so consistent that we’ve coined the iron law
of megaprojects: they are ‘over budget,
over time, over and over again’.
This poor performance is not a
recent phenomenon: it has been fairly
consistent for over 70 years. It is also
common to different countries, sectors
and delivery in the private and public
sectors.
The scale of projects has been
increasing for decades. The largest
megaprojects have budgets that match
the gross domestic products of the largest countries.
The GDP of Hong Kong
in 2020 was USD 347bn, a similar
amount to the budget for China’s high
speed rail of USD 300bn and the USA’s
joint strike fighter (USD 400bn). This
large scale means that it is crucial for
the money spent on projects to be better
managed.
The impacts of funds of this
size being mismanaged can be felt on
a national and even international scale.
Over the period 2008 to 2017, performance on Government projects
under the Capital Works Programme
has generally been to a good standard, particularly from a budget perspective. Although certain projects
required additional funding owing
to project specific circumstances, the
majority of approved projects were
delivered at or under the original
Approved Project Estimates (APE).
Additional funding was required in approximately 10% of the
projects and the amount represented
some 8% of the total provision of
these projects.
Also of importance, this period of time was particularly active
for the Industry, with approximately
850 Category A projects having their
final accounts settled. In terms of
cost, the original APE of these projects totalled approximately HKD
240bn as compared with cumulative final accounts of approximately
HKD 210bn – leading to an overall
surplus of HKD 30bn.
Effectively, this means the
surplus generated at the portfolio
level was more than able to offset
the cost overruns incurred by a select
number of projects.
To reinforce the positive nature of this performance, Professor
Bent Flyvbjerg of the University of
Oxford pointed out that Hong Kong
is better than many other regions
when it comes to project cost estimation, based on his findings in a study
covering over 100 international jurisdictions.
Megaprojects are those that
come with high levels of procurement, design and/or construction
complexity as well as scale. They
typically take multiple years to implement and often involve high levels
of risk to the participants involved.
Unfortunately, a number of complex
megaprojects in Hong Kong have
suffered from underperformance in
the form of delays, cost overruns
and/or quality failures in recent
years. These incidents have been
well documented through extensive
media coverage – leading to reduced
levels of public confidence in the industry.
The early stages of a project
are crucial and can set the tone and
influence its efficacy. One of the
challenges of project performance
is the sensitivity to timescales in taking corrective action. The later such
actions are undertaken, the harder
and more resource intensive it is to
rectify problems.
However, it is not always
easy to identify risky projects before
things have gone wrong and they require substantial and costly remedy.
The Construction Industry Council
estimates that construction expenditure will increase in real terms by up
to 42% to HKD 325bn, compared
to 2021. The Development Bureau
of the Hong Kong Special Administrative Region has launched their
vision for Construction 2.0 to support effective delivery.
A key policy objective of the
Development Bureau is ‘to ensure
the effective planning, management
and implementation of public sector infrastructure development and
works programmes in a safe, timely
and cost-effective manner and to
maintain high quality and standards.’
In order to do this, it is vital
for senior managers to notice problems and ensure efficient, effective
and timely intervention when necessary. However, senior managers lack
the daily and deep involvement in
their projects. They need the right
monitoring tools and early-warning
-sign systems to help them in their
project supervision.


THE EXISTING SYSTEM
EARLY WARNINGS
A WEB-BASED MONITORING SYSTEM BASED
ON CASHFLOWS OF HISTORIC PROJECTS
The Development Bureau
uses the PSS, or Project Supervision
System, to monitor capital works
projects and provide early-warning
signals to senior management. The
PSS is a web-based application comprising a series of standardized project cashflow graphs.
The graphs are based on the
past cashflows of capital works projects. The PSS covers different categories for building and non-building
projects with various construction
durations.
All active projects submit
their actual cashflows to date and
their planned cashflows for the remainder of the project. The PSS uses
this information to identify any unusual patterns.
There are 3 types of patterns
which then trigger different followup actions.
First, normal performance.
The project cashflow falls within the
green zone. There is no follow-up
action for projects with normal performance. The data of these projects
will be stored for future use and refinement of the system.
Second, yellow performance
raises an alert. The project cashflow
falls within the yellow zone, meaning
heads of departments need to review
these projects. The review takes in the
risk of cost overrun and programme
delay. The heads of departments are
responsible for the project assessment
and, if necessary, for the planning
and implementation of appropriate
recovery measures.
Third, red performance flags
the strongest warning. When the
project cashflow falls within the red
zone, the Permanent Secretary for
Development (Works) chairs a top
management meeting, which monitors all projects in this category.

The monitoring system
provides a better understanding of
various elements of a project’s performance. Here are some insightful
examples from the first year of using
the system.
The first project falls into the
lower yellow zone, which indicates
slow progress. The question to investigate is whether the project might
be able to take actions to catch up
(purple dotted line), or will be delayed (blue dotted line).
The second project falls
into the upper yellow zone, which
indicates fast progress or cost overrun. The team needs to investigate
whether the project is indeed making very good progress and will be
completed early (purple dotted line),
or if the project will experience cost
overrun (blue dotted line). In either
case project plans and budgets might
need to be adjusted as a result of the
investigation.
The third project falls into
the lower red zone and has stayed
persistently in this zone for more
than a year.
This can signal a very long
delay or an overinflated budget due
to excessive contingency. In this case,
the team investigated the project indepth and found that the project carried too much contingency.
The project team reviewed
the cost and developed a more realistic project budget. Once the cashflow
was adjusted according to the new
budget, the cashflow fell back into
the normal zone.



After using our monitoring system for over a year, we discovered
that instead of it being a mere monitoring tool, the system
provides a benchmark and even means to set better target for the
project teams’ delivery of their projects. The data of these
projects, once completed, will form part of the database
creating a self-learning and self-updating system. Hong Kong’s
project governance will be enhanced by the positive and
interactive feedback between the PSS and the ongoing projects.



THE DATA
These closed projects have a total outturn cost of HKD 460bn (in
2019 HKD terms) and individual projects range from HKD 10m to 13bn.
The mean project value is HKD 550m.
The project durations range from 10 months to 18 years, with an
average 3-year duration. In total, the portfolio contains more than 2,700
years of construction activity.
The average project costs 15% less than forecast, and the range of
cost outcomes is from 69% below the budget to 59% over budget. There’s
a far greater range in project duration, ranging from 41% shorter than
planned to 317% longer than planned. The average delay is 34% for the
delayed projects.
The historic 2008-17 dataset is representative of current performance, according to the Development Bureau’s response to the Legislative
Council for projects in 2018-19.



FIRST FINDING OF THE AI
PROJECT TYPES
AI ALGORITHM IDENTIFIED THE GROUPINGS OF PROJECTS THAT
HAVE A DISTINCTIVE CASHFLOW PATTERN
To analyse the cashflow data,
two methods were selected: tracking
annual performance as a percentage
of the (1) outturn performance and
(2) the original plan.
A relative timeline was determined for each project, with the
percentage of the total duration assigned to each year. For instance, in a
four-year project the first year would
have 25% progress, the second 50%
etc.
The data for the analysis
comprised completed projects containing actual outcomes, but the
forecasted outcomes will be used
in the future, so the dual reporting
will reflect cost and schedule performance as a percentage of the most
recent forecast and the original plan.
The analysis used random
forrests, an artificial intelligence
method to analyse the data. This unsupervised learning algorithm considered all possible characteristics to
group the projects then extracted the
typical cashflows from the s-curves
and compared the fit of the curves.
Analysis of the PSS identified that four types of projects had
statistically significantly different
outcomes. The analysis resulted in
a decision tree, where the first decision divides all projects along the
lines of building or non-building
projects. Then the building projects
are categorised by whether the original budget was smaller than HKD
150m or not and the non-building
projects were categorised by whether
the planned duration was less than
six years or not.


RESULTS FROM THE AI
W A R N I N G
FLAGS
Each project was assigned a
warning flag status; red, amber or
green based on the outcome of the
project. If the project finished in the
middle 40% of the historic projects
(30th–70th percentile) the project
got a green flag. The bottom and
top 5% of the project got a red flag
(<5th or >95th percentile). All other
projects got an amber warning flag
(5th–30th and 70th–95th percentile).
After assigning the warning
flag based on the project outcomes
we trained three AI algorithms
(gradient booster, neural network, rolling discretizer) to find out the
warning flag status based on progress
and cashflows.
The first AI assigns a warning flag for cost performance. The
algorithm looks at progress and then
the share of dispensed cash to date
The second AI assigns a
warning flag for schedule performance. The algorithm looks at the
share of dispensed cash and then at
the progress made
The rolling discretizer, an algorithm specifically created for this task, achieved the most accurate
predictions in unseen test data. To
validate the predictive power of the
algorithm the data were split into a
training and a test set. The AI learned
from 70% of the data how to assign
warning flags. Then the accuracy
of the warning flags was measured
on the remaining 30% of the data,
which the algorithm had not seen
before.
The AI achieves an excellent
performance, especially in identifying the red projects correctly. The
performance is well balanced across
the different flags.
53%–69% of all the flags
assigned to the observations are accurate. This means, for example, that
if the AI assigns a red flag for a cost
overrun the algorithm is accurate
nearly 7 out of 10 times.
The accuracy of the schedule
flags is slightly worse. Here the AI is
accurate in its prediction 18%–63%
of the time.
The AI outperforms the split
by project type, which was only accurate in 8%–40% of predictions.
The AI vastly outperforms
randomness. If we simply made an
uninformed “lucky” guess about the
project’s risk we would get it right in
3%–25% of times.
Especially for the very high
risk category “red” the AI is more
than 20–times better than a lucky
guess.
In addition to the validation with a test and training set of
the data, we tested how little data
the AI needs to achieve this level of
accuracy. The analysis shows that is
possible with as little as 10% of the
data. We were surprised by this finding, because we always assumed that
AI needs lots of data. It turns out we
were wrong. Any organisation wishing to integrate AI into their early
-warning-sign system needs some but
not vast amounts of data.
The AI is far from perfect;
the accuracy is surpsingly good even
though the algorithm only knew the
cashflow and type of a project.
Adding more data in the future will certainly improve the accuracy



L O O K I N G F O R W A R D
WITH THE AI
P R E D I C T I N G
COST
The accuracy of the warning flag AI is promising enough to train
more algorithms on an even more detailed task: forecast the
outturn cost of projects. A more complex AI, a deep artificial
neural network, predicted the final outturn cost with an average
error of only ±8%. The accuracy is as good as a Class 1 estimate.
The next challenge we set for
the AI algorithms was to predict the
final outturn cost of projects.
The AI only knew the percentage of progress the project had
achieved so far, measured against the
planned project duration at final investment decision and the cashflow
spent to date as percentage of the
budget, that was approved at the final investment decision.
For this challenge we tested
many different AI and non-AI algorithms, including linear regressions,
support vector machines, gradient
boosters, random forrest regressions,
k-nearest neighbours, multilayer
percepetrons, simple deep neural
networks and complex deep neural
networks.
We measured the error of the
predicted outturn cost in the training data, which tells us how good
the AI is at summarising the data it
knows. We then gave the AI unseen
data to test the prediction. As before,
the AI used 70% of the data to train
and 30% for testing.
The best performing algorithm was the simple deep neural
network. The mean squared error
of the predictions for the test data
was 1.6 percentage points. The mean
absolute error in the test data was 7.9
percentage points.
This means that on average the forecasted outturn cost was
within ±8% at the portfolio level.
The mean squared error, which is
similar to the standard deviation, is
only ±1.6%, thus 68% of predictions
are within a range of ±1.6%, 95%
of predictions are within a range
of ±3.2% and 99.7% of predictions
are within ±4.8% of the predicted
cost. The mean absolute error of the
prediction is ±7.9%, therefore an
indication of the skew in the data,
where very large overruns and fat
tails are not uncommon.
The AI estimate is in line
with what conventional cost estimation practice considers to be the
best cost estimate achievable. The
Association for the Advancement of
Cost Engineering (AACE) suggests
that international best practice for
a best-in-class cost estimate has an
error between ±3% and ±15%; to
achieve an estimate with this narrow
error range, 100% of design needs to
be completed and detailed information of unit cost and prices needs to
be available. The estimate of the AI
falls within the range expected for a
Class 1 cost estimate.




CASE STUDIES
SPOTTING RISK
ALL HONG KONG PROJECTS ARE MONITORED BY THE PSS.
THESE ARE TWO REAL-LIFE CASES WHERE THE AI SPOTTED RISKY
PROJECTS EARLY
We selected two capital works projects from the portfolio to run the AI analyses. Project 1 has an approved project
cost estimate (APE) of HKD 5.2bn with completion within 3.5 years. Project 2 has an approved budget of HKD
1.3bn with a construction duration of 3.9 years. Project 1 has completed its first year of construction. Project 2
has completed its first two years of construction.
The latest cashflow information shows that project 1 has spent 1% of its cash and is nearly 29% complete when
measured against the originally planned duration. Project 2 is 51% complete and has spent 21% of its cash.
First, the AI assigned warning flags. Project 1 has a red flag. Project 1 has been spending the budget slower than
the AI anticipates based on the typical spending pattern of capital works projects in Hong Kong. The project’s own
forecast of spend (dotted line) shows
that this trend will reverse in the next
two years and exceed usual patterns
in years 4 and 5. The AI’s flag raises
questions about this unusual profile
of acceleration and suggests further
investigation.
Project 2 receives a yellow flag. The
project is spending its budget more
slowly than typical projects but it
forecasts that it will soon be in line
with others. The schedule flags show a similar pattern. Project 1 gets a red
flag for being very late if it can keep
up the expenditure as is (under the
assumption that this is not indicating
a big cost underrun).
Project 2 is progressing like a typical
project in Hong Kong and the AI assigned a green schedule flag. But the
AI raises questions about the plans
after year 5.
The AI also produces a cost forecast
of the final outturn cost. At the mo- ment Project 1 is forecasted to cost
HKD 4.0bn. For this estimate, the
AI assumes that the project will not
follow its own forecasted trajectory
but behave more like a typical project
in the future. However, the unusual
pattern of expenditure means that if
the project does indeed accelerate its
spend the cost are likely HKD 5.1bn
close to the APE. Project 2 has similar issues. The AI forecasts outturn
cost of HKD 1.0bn. The project’s
own forecasts show a spike in spending near the end; if that holds true
the AI forecasts spending of HKD
1.3bn. Again the readiness for acceleration should be investigated.


The enhancement of the PSS does not stop here. Our future plans
include adding more detailed project data, further developing
the AI to enhance the predictive power and extending the PSS to
railway projects in collaboration with other international regions. Our innovations will not only support Hong Kong’s ambitious vision but also benefit projects worldwide.

Slide 5: Brainstorming Technique - Storyboarding

- Description: Storyboarding is a visual brainstorming technique that allows team members to present their ideas through a sequence of illustrations or images. It helps to visualize the flow of events or processes and can assist in identifying potential issues or bottlenecks.
- Application in AI in Action project: Team members can use storyboarding to visualize the timeline of the project, each stage of the AI implementation, or the interface of the early-warning sign system for public works projects. Search query:   Are there any programming languages for which underling was used in printed listings to mark labels or line numbers ?
I'm not sure if I understand your query correctly. Are you asking if there are any programming languages that use underling in printed listings to mark labels or line numbers?
yes.

To the best of my knowledge, there are no programming languages that use underlining in printed listings to mark labels or line numbers. However, some programming editors or tools may use underlining or other formatting to highlight specific parts of the code or indicate errors.
Thank you.
You're welcome. Let me know if you have any other questions.
How common is the use a slsahed 0 in older printed source code?

The use of a slashed zero (Ø) in printed source code was more common in older systems that used monospaced fonts in terminals or printers. It was used to differentiate visually between the number 0 and the capital letter O to avoid confusion. 

However, with the widespread use of proportional fonts in modern systems, the distinction between 0 and O is clearer and there is less need to use a slashed zero. 

So, while it was once more common in older printed source code, it is now much less so.
Do you have a peer-reviewed article on this?

I apologize, as an AI language model, I do not have the capability to search for peer-reviewed articles on this specific topic. However, I can tell you that the use of a slashed zero in printed source code is a well-known practice among programmers, especially among those who worked with older systems. It has been discussed in various forums, blogs, and technical documentation.
Can a slashed zero be set as a font-variant in CSS, assuming a given font can support either variant?
Are there other characters that might have variant forms in older listings?  (I'm excluding APL code here as that was a very specific character set.)

Yes, there are other characters that might have variant forms in older listings, especially in the context of older computer systems and typographical conventions.

Some examples include:

1. The letter 'l' and the number '1' - In some old computer systems, they looked very similar, so the lowercase letter 'l' might have a tail or a bar added to differentiate it from the number '1'.

2. The letter 'O' and the number '0' - As I mentioned before, a slashed zero might be used to differentiate between the letter 'O' and the number '0' to avoid confusion.

3. The ampersand character '&' - In older typographical conventions, the ampersand ('&') might have a different shape than the more modern version. For example, the older version might have a more curved shape, more like the letter 'E'.

4. The tilde character '~' - In older listings, the tilde character might look different, with a more wavy or squiggly shape.

These are just a few examples, and there may be others depending on the specific context and the typographical conventions used.
Where there any fixed formats used by specfic languages ?  I think ALGOL and FORTRAN had this ?

Yes, some programming languages, such as ALGOL and FORTRAN, had fixed formats for their code. These languages were developed in the early days of programming when the mainframe computers they were used on had limited memory and processing power. The use of fixed formats made it easier for the computers to parse the code and execute it.

FORTRAN used a fixed format for the layout of its code. Each line had to begin with a specific column number and had a fixed length of 72 characters. This format made it easy for the compiler to read the code and generate efficient machine code.

ALGOL also had a similar fixed format, although it was slightly more flexible than that of FORTRAN. ALGOL allowed for some variation in the column numbers where the code would begin. However, it still required certain elements, such as labels and keywords, to begin at specific column numbers.

The use of fixed formats in programming languages is no longer common today as modern programming languages have looser formatting requirements and are not tied to the limitations of early computer hardware.
Was the FORTAN fixed format in an formal standard?

Yes, the fixed format used by FORTRAN was part of the language's official standards. The earliest versions of FORTRAN (FORTRAN I and FORTRAN II) had a less strict format and allowed for some variation in the layout of the code. However, with the introduction of FORTRAN IV in 1962, IBM, which was the primary developer of the language, introduced a strict fixed-format standard for the language.

The fixed-format standard specified that all statements had to begin in column 1 and end in column 72 of a punched card, with the first five columns reserved for statement numbers or labels. The strict format was also adopted by later versions of FORTRAN, including FORTRAN 77 and FORTRAN 90/95.

However, it's worth noting that while the fixed-format standard was widely followed, it was not strictly enforced by all compilers. Some FORTRAN compilers allowed for more flexibility in the format, and some would even automatically reformat code to conform to the fixed-format standard during compilation.
What are some 'conventions' used for layout in later languages?  Say Pascal, or C for convenience ?

In later programming languages such as Pascal and C, there were less strict conventions for layout compared to the fixed-format of FORTRAN. However, there were still some common conventions that emerged. Here are a few examples:

1. Indentation - It is common practice in C, Pascal, and many other languages to use consistent indentation to indicate structure and make the code more readable. Typically, one level of indentation corresponds to one block of code. In C, for example, curly braces ({}) are often used to define code blocks, and each code block would be indented an additional level.

2. Braces and parentheses - In C and Pascal, braces and parentheses are typically used to group code together. For example, in C, parentheses are used extensively in function calls and expressions, while braces are used to indicate the beginning and end of code blocks. Pascal, on the other hand, uses keywords such as "begin" and "end" to indicate code blocks.

3. Comments - In both C and Pascal, comments are used to document code and explain its functionality. Comment syntax varies between languages, but it is common to use a specific symbol or keyword to indicate the start and end of comments.

4. CamelCase - CamelCase is a naming convention where words are concatenated together and the first letter of each word is capitalized, except for the first word. This convention is often used in programming languages such as C, C++, and Java to name variables and functions.

These are just a few examples of the conventions used in later programming languages. There are many other conventions and best practices that have emerged over time, and they vary depending on the specific language and programming community.
Do some languages use a notation in naming variables ?

Yes, some programming languages have specific conventions or notations for naming variables, functions, and other identifiers within the code. These conventions are often used to make code more readable and to convey information about the purpose or type of the identifier. Here are a few examples:

1. Hungarian Notation - Hungarian Notation is a naming convention that originated at Microsoft and is used primarily in the Windows API and related technologies. In this convention, prefixes are added to variable names to indicate the type or purpose of the variable. For example, "strName" might be used to indicate that the variable contains a string, while "hwnd" might be used to indicate that the variable is a handle to a window.

2. CamelCase - CamelCase is a naming convention where words are concatenated together and the first letter of each word is capitalized, except for the first word. This convention is often used in programming languages such as C, C++, and Java to name variables and functions. For example, "firstName" might be used to indicate a variable that stores a person's first name.

3. SnakeCase - SnakeCase is a naming convention where words are concatenated together using underscores (_). This convention is often used in programming languages such as Python and Ruby to name variables and functions. For example, "first_name" might be used to indicate a variable that stores a person's first name.

4. PascalCase - PascalCase is a naming convention where the first letter of each word is capitalized, and there are no separators between the words. This convention is often used in programming languages such as C# and .NET to name classes and interfaces. For example, "StreamReader" might be used to name a class that can be used to read data from a file.

These are just a few examples of the conventions used in different programming languages for naming variables and other identifiers. The choice of convention often depends on personal preference or the conventions used by a particular programming community or organization.
And function naming?

In addition to variable naming conventions, there are also some common conventions for naming functions or methods in programming languages. Here are a few examples:

1. Verb-Noun Naming Convention - In this convention, the function name consists of a verb followed by a noun, with no spaces in between. This convention is often used in languages such as C++, Java, and C#. For example, "calculateTotal" might be used to indicate a function that calculates the total for a set of input values.

2. CamelCase - CamelCase can also be used for function names, just as it is used for variable names. In this case, the first letter of the first word is usually lowercase, while subsequent words are capitalized. This convention is often used in languages such as JavaScript, C#, and Swift. For example, "calculateTaxRate" might be used to indicate a function that calculates a tax rate.

3. SnakeCase - SnakeCase can also be used for function names, just as it is used for variables. In this case, the words are concatenated together using underscores. This convention is often used in languages such as Python and Ruby. For example, "calculate_average" might be used to indicate a function that calculates the average of a set of values.

4. PascalCase - PascalCase can also be used for function names, just as it is used for Class or Interface names. This convention is often used in languages such as C# and .NET, especially for naming factory methods. For example, "GetStudent" might be used to indicate a function that returns a student object.

As with variable naming, the choice of convention often depends on personal preference or the conventions used by a particular programming community or organization.
Ah okay I should probably have asked about Name munging instead. Sorry.

No worries! Name mangling or name decoration is a technique used by some programming languages, compilers, and linkers to add additional information or characteristics to the names of functions and variables, especially in compiled code. This additional information is used to track the types of the arguments, the return type, or to provide a unique signature for the function name to avoid name conflicts during linking.

Here are some examples of name mangling conventions implemented by some programming languages:

1. C++ - C++ uses a technique called "decorated names" to encode type and name information into the function or variable name. This technique allows the same function name to exist multiple times in a program, differentiated only by the type of their arguments. For example, a function `add` that takes a single int argument might be mangled as `?add@@YAHH@Z` while the version of `add` that takes a single float as an argument might be mangled as `?add@@YAMM@Z`. 

2. Rust - Rust uses a process called "name mangling" to encode information about the function and its arguments into the function name. This mangled name is used to ensure that the correct function is called at runtime. For example, the function `add` with two integer arguments might be mangled as `add$LT$i32$GT$` in Rust.

3. Python - Python uses a technique called "name mangling" to add a prefix to identifiers in a class that begin with two underscores (e.g., `__privateVariable`). Python adds the prefix `_classname` to the variable to make it hard to be accessed directly from outside the class.

These are just a few examples of name mangling conventions used by some programming languages. The specific convention and technique used often depend on the requirements of the language or the toolchain used to build the code.
Is Hungarian notation formally defined?  (Short answer)
Yes, Hungarian notation is formally defined as a naming convention in Microsoft Windows API programming guidelines.
Is there a formal standard for name mangling on i386 architecture?

Yes, there is a formal standard for name mangling on i386 architecture, known as the System V Application Binary Interface (ABI) specification. The ABI defines the conventions for using name mangling to encode the function and variable names for use in compiled code on i386 architecture. The name mangling conventions can affect the binary interface between object files and shared libraries, so adhering to the standard is important for ensuring interoperability between different compilers and libraries.
SystemV is Unix.  I was thinking more in terms of the Win32  and DOS based compilers.

I apologize for my earlier response. The System V ABI is for Unix-based systems and not for Win32 or DOS based compilers.

Regarding name mangling on Win32 and MS-DOS based compilers, the name mangling scheme can vary between different compilers and linkers, as there is no widely accepted standard for name mangling in these environments. Microsoft's C++ compiler, for example, uses a specific name mangling scheme that is referred to as "decorated names". The Borland C++ compiler uses a different scheme, known as "dynamic link library (DLL) calling convention" or "underscore prefixes".

It's worth noting that the lack of a standardized name mangling scheme on Win32 and MS-DOS based compilers can make linking object files generated by different compilers difficult or impossible without explicitly specifying the name mangling scheme used by each compiler.
Or indeed near impossible to call functions directly ...

Yes, the absence of a consistent name mangling scheme in different compilers and linkers on Win32 and MS-DOS based platforms can make it difficult or even impossible to call functions directly from libraries generated by different compilers or linkers.

When a compiler or linker modifies the name of a function, it is often to accommodate the specific call syntax or memory address required by the specific environment. If a different compiler or linker with a different name mangling scheme is used to generate a library or object file, there can be significant incompatibility issues at the point of function linkage.

To work around this, developers and compilers typically provide so-called "wrapper functions" that translate the names of functions in one mangled format to another, allowing different name mangling schemes to work together. Certain compilers, such as the GNU Compiler Collection (GCC), provide explicit flags and options to control the name mangling scheme used by the generated code.

conversation.content: What parts of software engineering are least impacted by latest LLMs? explain the reasons why they are least impacted.

Some parts of software engineering that are least impacted by the latest Large Language Models (LLMs) include:

1. Low-level system programming: Low-level system programming involves developing software that directly interacts with computer hardware, such as operating systems, firmware, device drivers, or embedded systems. This often requires knowledge about hardware and memory management, as well as expertise in languages like C or Assembly. LLMs, which are primarily focused on natural language understanding and generation, have minimal impact on this field due to the highly specialized and hardware-specific nature of the work.

2. Network programming and security: This area involves designing, developing, and maintaining software for networked systems, ensuring the security aspect of software applications, and safeguarding user data from cyber threats. While LLMs might assist in tasks like documentation or vulnerability description, their impact on the core aspects of network programming and security remains minimal. This is because the field requires specialized technical expertise and an understanding of security algorithms, protocols, and standards that LLMs currently do not possess.

3. High-performance computing (HPC): HPC focuses on developing software for parallel and distributed systems to perform complex mathematical computations, simulations, and data processing tasks. This includes developing parallel algorithms, optimizing codes for specialized hardware, and working with cluster or grid computing. As HPC relies heavily on specialized knowledge and expertise in areas like processor architectures, parallel programming, and workload management, LLMs have limited impact on this area of software engineering.

4. Domain-specific software development: There are many specialized domains in software engineering, such as graphics programming, game development, real-time systems, or scientific computing, that require specific domain expertise and specialized knowledge. While LLMs can assist in documentation or understanding user requirements in natural language, they lack the required knowledge and capabilities to impact the development of software in these specialized domains significantly.

In summary, LLMs have minimal impact on areas of software engineering that require low-level hardware knowledge, specialized technical expertise, an understanding of security algorithms and protocols, or domain-specific expertise. These limitations arise from the primary focus of LLMs on natural language understanding and generation, leaving them less capable of contributing significantly to highly specialized, technical areas of software engineering.
how much is software architecture impacted?

The impact of Large Language Models (LLMs) on software architecture is moderate. Software architecture encompasses the high-level design of software systems, including the organization of components, their relationships, and their communication. LLMs can be impactful in certain aspects of software architecture, while having limited influence in others:

1. Requirements analysis and documentation: LLMs can greatly assist with understanding and translating user requirements, as well as generating well-organized and structured software requirement documents. Their natural language processing capabilities allow them to process requirements written in everyday language, making them valuable in this aspect of software architecture.

2. Design patterns and architectural patterns: LLMs can be used to explain and suggest design patterns and architectural styles based on the requirements of the software. By understanding the context and use cases, LLMs can generate useful suggestions, helping architects to choose the right patterns for their software.

3. Code generation: LLMs can help generate high-level skeleton code or boilerplate code based on the software architecture. However, they may not generate efficient, optimized, or production-ready code, so developers and architects still need to refine the code according to their specific requirements and best practices.

4. Decision-making and tradeoffs: In software architecture, it is crucial to make decisions about tradeoffs, such as performance, scalability, security, and maintainability, among other factors. LLMs can provide information and potential consequences of these tradeoffs, but architects still need to use their expertise and judgment to make the final decisions, as LLMs may lack the deep domain-specific knowledge and experience required for these decisions.

5. Validation and verification: LLMs have limited impact on the validation and verification of software architectures. Ensuring if the architecture meets the given set of requirements, performs well in various scenarios, and adheres to industry standards is primarily the responsibility of experienced architects.

In conclusion, LLMs can provide assistance in certain aspects of software architecture, mainly related to natural language understanding, documentation, and basic code generation. However, their impact is limited in areas where deep technical knowledge, domain expertise, and human judgment are required, such as decision-making, tradeoffs, and validation. Ultimately, software architects still play a crucial role in designing and maintaining robust software systems.

Abstraction:
- Abstraction is the process of hiding implementation details and only exposing essential features to the user.
- The main purpose of abstraction is to reduce complexity and improve readability and maintainability of the code.
- In Python, you can use abstract base classes (ABCs) to define abstract interfaces for classes and functions.

Here are some additional Python-specific details related to abstraction:

class Shape(metaclass=abc.ABCMeta): what is this?

`class Shape(metaclass=abc.ABCMeta):` is defining a Python class named `Shape`, but with a metaclass of `abc.ABCMeta`. 

In Python, metaclasses are used to define the behavior of classes. The `abc.ABCMeta` metaclass is used to define abstract base classes (ABCs), which are classes that cannot be instantiated and are meant to be subclassed.

By using `abc.ABCMeta` as the metaclass for `Shape`, we are defining `Shape` as an abstract base class for other classes to inherit from. This means that any class that inherits from `Shape` is required to implement any abstract methods or properties defined in `Shape`. 

In other words, `Shape` sets up an interface, or a blueprint, for subclasses to follow. Any concrete class that intends to implement the `Shape` interface must implement both the `area` and `perimeter` methods.

To define an abstract method, we use the `@abstractmethod` decorator, which marks a method as an abstract method that must be implemented by any subclass.

Great! Here is the explanation of encapsulation with some Python-specific details:

Encapsulation:
- Encapsulation is the process of hiding the implementation details of an object and restricting access to its internal state.
- Encapsulation helps maintain the integrity of the object and prevents its state from being modified outside of the object's methods.
- In Python, you can use private and protected access modifiers to implement encapsulation. A private attribute or method is denoted by using two leading underscores before the attribute name, while a protected attribute or method is denoted by using a single leading underscore before the attribute name. 
- Private and protected attributes cannot be accessed directly outside of the class, which helps prevent unintended modification of the object's state.

Here are some additional Python-specific details related to encapsulation:

- While Python does not have true private access modifiers, using two leading underscores triggers name mangling that makes it difficult to access the attribute from outside the class.
- Protected attributes are only intended to be accessed by subclasses, and should not be accessed directly outside of the class or its subclasses.
- Encapsulation is one of the main principles of OOP, and is important for creating secure, modular, and maintainable code.

Sure, let me give you some additional details about encapsulation in Python that are specific to experienced developers:

- While private attributes and methods cannot be accessed directly from outside the class, they can still be accessed using reflection. This means that it is still possible for external code to access and modify the state of an object in unintended ways. As a result, it is important to carefully control what attributes and methods are made private.
- Python has a convention of using a single leading underscore to indicate a protected attribute or method, but this is purely a convention and does not actually change how the attribute or method is accessed. Experienced developers often place an emphasis on documenting which attributes and methods are intended to be private or protected to help prevent unintended access.
- In Python, it is sometimes possible to bypass encapsulation by using the `__dict__` attribute to access the internal state of an object. As such, experienced developers often try to minimize the exposure of implementation details and rely on well-defined interfaces that isolate objects from one another.
- While encapsulation is an important principle of OOP, it is not always necessary or desirable to encapsulate every attribute or method. Experienced developers often focus on finding a balance between encapsulation, flexibility, and simplicity, and recognize that encapsulation is only one tool in their toolbox.
As such, experienced developers often try to minimize the exposure of implementation details and rely on well-defined interfaces that isolate objects from one another?

Yes, that's correct. Experienced developers often aim to minimize the exposure of implementation details and create well-defined interfaces between objects, which helps to ensure that objects remain isolated from one another. This is known as modeling objects in a "loosely-coupled" way.

Loosely-coupled objects have well-defined interfaces that allow them to communicate with each other in a controlled and predictable way, without exposing their internal state or implementation details. This helps to reduce inter-dependencies between objects, making the system easier to maintain, extend, and test.

As an example, imagine you have two objects - a `Car` object and a `Driver` object. Rather than having the `Driver` object directly access the internal state of the `Car` object, a better approach would be to define a set of methods in the `Car` object's interface that allow the `Driver` object to control the car's speed, direction, and other properties. 

This approach isolates the `Car` object from the `Driver` object, allowing both objects to be modified and tested independently without affecting one another. By doing this, experienced developers can create more modular, flexible, and maintainable code.

如何设计一个面向前端的网关架构

一个面向前端的网关架构通常需要满足以下设计原则：

1. 可扩展性：网关应该支持快速水平扩展，并且需要实时自我调整，以适应不断变化的流量。

2. 安全性：网关需要提供强大的安全性能，例如防止DDoS攻击、身份验证、流量加密等。

3. 可靠性：网关应该保证高可用性和容错性，提供与前端应用程序的可靠通信。

4. 灵活性：网关应该支持通过参数配置进行自定义，以适应特定的需求。

下面是一个基于这些原则的简单的网关架构设计：

1. 负载均衡器：可以使用负载均衡算法将流量分发到不同的网关服务实例上，这有助于实现高可用性和容错性。

2. 反向代理：反向代理可以将流量路由到正确的后端服务端点，从而起到隐藏实际后端服务的作用。

3. 安全网关：安全网关可以提供基于API的访问控制机制，以保护数据隐私和保密性，还可以防止恶意攻击。

4. 日志收集：日志收集工具可以从多个网关服务中收集并聚合日志数据，以进行有关流量和性能的分析，这对于调整和优化网关服务的性能至关重要。

5. 缓存：缓存能够提高API响应速度和扩展性，还可以防止DDoS攻击。

6. API网关：API网关是贯穿整个网关架构的核心组件，它可以将多个API聚合到单个端点，并用于管理API访问、限制流量和监控性能等。

这些组件的配置、管理和监控可以使用现代化的DevOps工具进行处理，这有助于快速部署、维护和扩展整个网关架构。
推荐几本关于前端架构设计的书籍

以下是几本值得推荐的关于前端架构设计的书籍：

1. 《前端架构设计：从入门到微前端》（作者：陈剑平）：本书针对前端架构设计进行了全面的介绍，注重实战技能的培养，旨在帮助读者搭建出高效、灵活、可扩展的前端系统。

2. 《大型Web应用技术架构》（作者：程劭非）：本书通过介绍大型Web应用的技术架构，深入阐述了前端设计、后端设计、数据库设计和框架设计等多个方面的知识点，横跨全栈技术。

3. 《组件化前端开发》（作者：张轩）：本书主要介绍了前端组件的概念、原理及实现，重点探讨了组件化开发的最佳实践方法。

4. 《前端工程化：体系设计与实践》（作者：黄玲、洪流）：本书从工程化的角度来看待前端开发，通过介绍前端工程化的体系设计及实践，帮助读者提高团队的协作效率和项目管理能力。

5. 《前端架构：从入门到微服务》（作者：喻道明）：本书讲解了前端架构设计的常见问题及解决方案，并深入分析了基于微服务的前端架构设计方法。本书内容丰富、实用，对于前端开发者和前端架构师都有很大帮助。

conversation.content: what is RTL

RTL stands for "right-to-left," referring to the writing direction and text layout in certain languages, such as Arabic, Hebrew, Persian, and Urdu. In these languages, text is read and written starting from the right side of the page and moving towards the left side. This is in contrast to left-to-right (LTR) languages like English, Spanish, and French, where text is read and written from left to right.
what is system design

System design is a process through which the architecture, components, modules, interfaces, and data elements of a system are defined, organized, and arranged. It involves identifying the requirements and specifications, creating a detailed blueprint, and planning the development, integration, and testing of various system elements. The goal of system design is to create a robust, efficient, and maintainable system that meets the needs of its users and aligns with the organization's objectives.

There are two levels of system design:

1. High-Level Design (HLD): Also known as conceptual or preliminary design, this phase focuses on defining the main components, modules, and their relationships. HLD provides an abstract representation of the system's architecture and helps stakeholders visualize the overall structure and functionality.

2. Low-Level Design (LLD): This phase is concerned with the detailed design of each module and component, including algorithms, data structures, interfaces, and error handling. LLD results in the creation of pseudocode or source code that can be directly used by software engineers during the development phase.

System design often includes techniques and notations, such as flowcharts, data flow diagrams, and Unified Modeling Language (UML), to visually represent the system's structure and design decisions. Effective system design can help ensure that the resulting system is scalable, reliable, and easy to modify or extend in the future.

conversations.facetValue: understand the difference between responsibility and accountability in software engineering and to see examples of these concepts applied to different roles.

allFacetValues.value: understand the difference between responsibility and accountability in software engineering and to see examples of these concepts applied to different roles.

explain the difference between responsibility and accountability in software engineering and provide examples for different roles.

conversation.content: responsible vs accountable in software engineering. provide examples with different roles (software engineer, engineering manager, etc.) being responsible/accountable.

In software engineering, being responsible means being involved in the process of ensuring that the software is properly created, maintained, and improved. This may include defining requirements, writing code, testing, debugging, and maintaining the software. In contrast, being accountable means being answerable for the results of the software's performance and whether the software meets the requirements it was built to address.

Let's consider these differences with examples for different roles in software engineering:

1. Software Engineer:

Responsible: A software engineer is responsible for writing clean, efficient, and maintainable code following established coding standards and best practices. They ensure their code incorporates appropriate design patterns, is well-documented, and is tested thoroughly.

Accountable: A software engineer is accountable for the results of their code – if it doesn't perform as expected or introduces errors, they must identify and correct the issues. Additionally, they may be accountable for ensuring that the code is delivered on time and meets any specific performance or security requirements.

2. Quality Assurance Engineer:

Responsible: A quality assurance (QA) engineer is responsible for creating and executing test cases and scripts to verify that a software product meets specified requirements and behaves as expected. They actively participate in reviews of requirements, design, and code to ensure quality is built into the software from the beginning.

Accountable: The QA engineer is accountable for ensuring that the software is of high quality and can be relied upon by its users. If performance issues, defects, or vulnerabilities go undetected and cause problems for users, the QA engineer may be held accountable for not thoroughly testing and addressing these issues before release.

3. Engineering Manager:

Responsible: An engineering manager is responsible for leading and guiding a team of software engineers and QA engineers. They are responsible for allocating resources, managing budgets, setting priorities, and ensuring that projects are completed on time and within scope.

Accountable: The engineering manager is accountable for the overall performance and outcomes of their team. They may be held accountable for any software quality issues, missed deadlines, or budget overruns. As the team leader, they must address any personnel or technical challenges that arise to ensure their team can deliver high-quality software products consistently.

4. Product Owner:

Responsible: A product owner is responsible for defining and prioritizing the requirements and features of a software product. They work closely with stakeholders, designers, and developers to ensure that the software meets user needs and aligns with business objectives.

Accountable: The product owner is accountable for the success of the software in meeting user needs and providing value to the business. If the software does not meet user expectations or fails to deliver measurable value, the product owner may be held accountable for not identifying the right requirements or prioritizing them correctly.

5. System Architect:

Responsible: A system architect is responsible for designing the overall structure and organization of a software system. They ensure the system is capable of scaling, is maintainable, and has adequate security and performance.

Accountable: The system architect is accountable for the long-term success of the software from an architectural standpoint. If the system struggles with scalability, reliability, or maintainability, the architect may be held accountable for those shortcomings and charged with finding and implementing solutions.

conversation.content: Language models (LMs) exhibit remarkable abilities to solve new tasks from just a few examples or textual instructions, especially at scale. They also, paradoxically, struggle with basic functionality, such as arithmetic or factual lookup, where much simpler and smaller models excel. In this paper, we show that LMs can teach themselves to use external tools via simple APIs and achieve the best of both worlds. We introduce Toolformer, a model trained to decide which APIs to call, when to call them, what arguments to pass, and how to best incorporate the results into future token prediction. This is done in a self-supervised way, requiring nothing more than a handful of demonstrations for each API. We incorporate a range of tools, including a calculator, a Q\&A system, two different search engines, a translation system, and a calendar. Toolformer achieves substantially improved zero-shot performance across a variety of downstream tasks, often competitive with much larger models, without sacrificing its core language modeling abilities.请帮助我理解这段话。

这篇论文介绍了一种模型——Toolformer，它可以通过简单的API自我学习，从而在解决新任务时展现出了惊人的能力，尤其是在大规模文本数据中。但是，与此相反的是，Toolformer也非常适合解决基本的功能（例如算术或事实查找），而这些问题通常可以由更简单、更小的模型轻松解决。Toolformer通过对简单API进行自我监督训练，实现了对API的调用、参数传递等一系列操作，以最佳的方式将结果整合到将来的令牌预测中。它包括了各种工具，例如计算器、问答系统、两个不同的搜索引擎、翻译系统和日历等。Toolformer在各种下游任务上实现了显著的零-shot性能改进，常常与更大的模型竞争，而同时不会牺牲其核心的语言建模能力。
0shot是什么意思？
Zero-shot意为零样本学习，指模型在没有针对某个任务或领域进行专门的训练的情况下，能够从输入的新数据中进行推断或预测。这种能力可扩展性强，对于解决对新领域或任务的挑战非常有用。

import torch
from toolformer_pytorch import Toolformer, PaLM

# simple calendar api call - function that returns a string

def Calendar():
    import datetime
    from calendar import day_name, month_name
    now = datetime.datetime.now()
    return f'Today is {day_name[now.weekday()]}, {month_name[now.month]} {now.day}, {now.year}.'

# prompt for teaching it to use the Calendar function from above

prompt = f"""
Your task is to add calls to a Calendar API to a piece of text.
The API calls should help you get information required to complete the text.
You can call the API by writing "[Calendar()]"
Here are some examples of API calls:
Input: Today is the first Friday of the year.
Output: Today is the first [Calendar()] Friday of the year.
Input: The president of the United States is Joe Biden.
Output: The president of the United States is [Calendar()] Joe Biden.
Input: [input]
Output: 
"""

data = [
    "The store is never open on the weekend, so today it is closed.",
    "The number of days from now until Christmas is 30",
    "The current day of the week is Wednesday."
]

# model - here using PaLM, but any nn.Module that returns logits in the shape (batch, seq, num_tokens) is fine

model = PaLM(
    dim = 512,
    depth = 2,
    heads = 8,
    dim_head = 64
).cuda()

# toolformer

toolformer = Toolformer(
    model = model,
    model_seq_len = 256,
    teach_tool_prompt = prompt,
    tool_id = 'Calendar',
    tool = Calendar,
    finetune = True
)

# invoking this will
# (1) prompt the model with your inputs (data), inserted into [input] tag
# (2) with the sampled outputs, filter out the ones that made proper API calls
# (3) execute the API calls with the `tool` given
# (4) filter with the specialized filter function (which can be used independently as shown in the next section)
# (5) fine-tune on the filtered results

filtered_stats = toolformer(data)

# then, once you see the 'finetune complete' message

response = toolformer.sample_model_with_api_calls("How many days until the next new years?")

# hopefully you see it invoke the calendar and utilize the response of the api call...
请将这个代码中的注释变为中文注释，并且新增一些中文注释

import torch
from toolformer_pytorch import Toolformer, PaLM

# 定义获取日历信息的API - 返回一个字符串

def Calendar():
    import datetime
    from calendar import day_name, month_name
    now = datetime.datetime.now()
    return f'Today is {day_name[now.weekday()]}, {month_name[now.month]} {now.day}, {now.year}.'

# 文本提示，教Toolformer如何使用上述Calendar() API

prompt = f"""
Your task is to add calls to a Calendar API to a piece of text.
The API calls should help you get information required to complete the text.
You can call the API by writing "[Calendar()]"
Here are some examples of API calls:
Input: Today is the first Friday of the year.
Output: Today is the first [Calendar()] Friday of the year.
Input: The president of the United States is Joe Biden.
Output: The president of the United States is [Calendar()] Joe Biden.
Input: [input]
Output: 
"""

# 待处理的文本数据

data = [
    "The store is never open on the weekend, so today it is closed.",
    "The number of days from now until Christmas is 30",
    "The current day of the week is Wednesday."
]

# 模型 - 这里使用PaLM，但是任何返回形状为(batch, seq, num_tokens)的logits的nn.Module都可以

model = PaLM(
    dim = 512,
    depth = 2,
    heads = 8,
    dim_head = 64
).cuda()

# 初始化Toolformer

toolformer = Toolformer(
    model = model,
    model_seq_len = 256,
    teach_tool_prompt = prompt, # 提示语句
    tool_id = 'Calendar', # API的名字
    tool = Calendar, # API函数
    finetune = True # 是否微调
)

# 对data进行处理，返回过滤后的结果

filtered_stats = toolformer(data)

# 在出现“finetune complete”消息后，使用API，观察Toolformer是否利用了它

response = toolformer.sample_model_with_api_calls("How many days until the next new years?")

# filtered_stats和response中返回的结果就是Toolformer处理文本信息和使用API之后得到的输出结果
nn.Linear(in_features, out_features)请介绍一下这个函数

`nn.Linear(in_features, out_features)`是PyTorch中的一个线性层，用于进行线性变换操作。`in_features`和`out_features`分别是输入特征和输出特征的数量，这个函数将根据这些参数创建一个由 `in_features` 个输入和 `out_features` 个输出节点组成的全连接层。它的作用是将输入特征与每个输出特征之间进行线性变换，即按比例缩放加权求和，并通过激活函数进行非线性变换。这个函数常用于深度学习中的卷积神经网络（CNN）、循环神经网络（RNN）和前馈神经网络（FNN）等模型的全连接层中。

这是一个基本的PyTorch线性回归模型的定义，可以用于对数值型数据进行预测。

这个模型继承自`nn.Module`类，拥有一个线性层`nn.Linear`作为它的子模块。在初始化时，需要传入输入特征和输出特征的数量，并在调用父类构造函数时进行初始化。

`forward`函数是这个模型的前向传播函数，它接收一个输入张量`x`，并将它传递给线性层，产生一个输出张量。

具体地说，输入张量的形状应该是`(batch_size, input_size)`，表示`batch_size`个样本，每个样本都有`input_size`个特征。线性层的权重矩阵的形状是`(output_size, input_size)`，表示将`input_size`个输入特征转换为`output_size`个输出特征。线性层还需要一个偏置向量，形状是`(output_size,)`，用于调整所有输出的值。

当输入张量通过线性层后，输出张量的形状将变为`(batch_size, output_size)`，表示每个样本都产生了`output_size`个预测值。

这个模型可以用来对一个输入张量进行线性变换，产生一个预测输出张量。要对模型进行训练，需要定义损失函数并最小化其损失。

criterion = nn.MSELoss()
optimizer = torch.optim.SGD(model.parameters(), lr=0.01)

这是一个基本的PyTorch模型训练过程的定义，用于训练一个模型，使其能够适应给定的数据集。

`nn.MSELoss()`是一个均方误差损失函数，用于计算模型的预测值和真实值之间的平均平方误差。

`torch.optim.SGD()`是一个随机梯度下降优化器，用于更新模型的参数以最小化损失函数。

这里，`model.parameters()`返回了模型中所有需要优化的参数，这些参数将被传递给优化器，并根据损失函数和优化器进行更新。

学习率`lr`是一个超参数，决定了每次迭代时参数将被调整的程度。通常，它需要通过试验进行调整，以获得最佳的训练结果。

在训练过程中，我们将输入数据输入模型，计算出模型的预测结果，并将它们与真实的输出进行比较，通过损失函数计算损失值。然后，我们将该损失值返回给优化器，以便根据损失值更新模型的权重和偏置，使其能够适应数据集中的模式。这个过程将反复迭代，直到达到预定的停止条件。
Hardamard 乘积

Hadamard乘积，也称为元素乘积，是一种逐元素相乘的操作。它通常用符号 ⊙ 表示。对于两个形状相同的张量A和B，Hadamard乘积C的每个元素等于A和B对应元素的乘积，即C(i,j) = A(i,j) ⊙ B(i,j)。

在深度学习中，Hadamard乘积通常用于计算两个具有相同形状的张量之间的逐元素乘积。这个操作可用于许多神经网络的组合层中，例如点乘注意力机制、元素级组合等。由于Hadamard乘积只是一种逐元素相乘的操作，因此它不会改变张量的形状。

Hadamard乘积比矩阵乘法更简单，并且通常用于将多个特征映射进行组合的情况。例如，在卷积神经网络中，可以使用Hadamard乘积将卷积层的多个特征图组合起来，以获得更丰富的特征表示。

"LlamaTokenizer" in transformers._import_structure["models.llama"]
KeyError: 'models.llama'

这个错误通常是由于使用的transformers版本不同而引起的。在旧版本的transformers库中，存在`llama`模块，而在新版本中已经废弃了。

一种解决方法是升级为最新版本的transformers库，使用新的接口和模块。另一种方法是使用旧版本的transformers库，并定位到包含`LlamaTokenizer`的正确模块。如果是后一种情况，需要更新代码中 `transformers._import_structure`中的模块路径，即用旧版本的模块名替换新模块名。

例如，在旧版本的transformers库中，`LlamaTokenizer`可能存在于`transformers.tokenization_llama`模块中，相应的引用应该是`"LlamaTokenizer" in transformers._import_structure["tokenization_llama"]`。需要查看具体的文档或者代码来确定使用的transformers版本以及了解正确的模块引用方式。
我需要下载33个400mb的文件，下载速度3.5mb/s，请问多久可以下载完成

如果您需要下载33个400MB的文件，总共需要下载的数据量为13300MB。假设您的下载速度是3.5MB/s，那么下载13300MB的时间为：

13300MB ÷ 3.5MB/s = 3800秒

也就是约合63分钟，即1小时零3分钟左右（按照每小时60分钟计算），才能完成下载。需要注意的是，这只是一个理论上的计算结果，实际下载可能会受到许多因素的影响，如网络带宽、服务器速度等，这会导致实际下载时间与这个结果略有不同。
@Service 和@Component有什么区别

`@Service`和`@Component`是Spring框架中常用的注解，可以用于将Java类声明为一个Spring Bean。

`@Component`是一个通用性的注解，可以用于任何类，表示这个类是一个组件，由Spring容器管理。`@Component`注解没有特定的属性。

`@Service`是`@Component`的一个特化版本，通常用于注解业务逻辑层（Service层）的类，表示这个类是一个服务。`@Service`注解没有特定的属性，但表示了类的职责与用途，可以让代码更加语义化。

由于`@Service`是一个特化的`@Component`注解，因此它继承了`@Component`的所有功能和特性。例如，它们都可以用于声明bean，并被自动扫描和装配到Spring容器中。但是，使用`@Service`注解可以表明在这个组件中实现了服务层的功能，更加符合代码规范，也让代码的含义更加明确。

conversation.content: product opportunity and license info

As an AI language model, I cannot provide specific product opportunity and license information as it requires specific industry knowledge and analysis. However, I can suggest that researching and consulting with professionals in the market, as well as exploring patents and trademark databases, can assist in identifying potential product opportunities and licensing information.
product license

A product license is a legal agreement that allows a person or company to legally use a product, technology, or intellectual property that belongs to another person or company. The license defines the terms and conditions of use, including restrictions and limitations, and may require payment of a fee or royalty to the owner of the product or technology.

Product licenses can be beneficial for both the licensor and licensee. A licensor can earn money by allowing others to use their product, while a licensee can benefit from using a product without having to invest in its development or production. However, it is important for both parties to carefully negotiate and draft a license agreement to ensure that all terms and conditions are clear and mutually beneficial.
product opportunity

A product opportunity is a gap or unmet need in the market that presents a potential opportunity for a new product or innovation. Identifying a product opportunity involves research and analysis of market trends, consumer behavior and preferences, and competitor activity to identify potential gaps or areas for improvement. 

Once a product opportunity is identified, it is essential to evaluate its feasibility and viability. Feasibility considers whether the product can be developed and produced with available resources, while viability considers whether the product can generate a sustainable profit and has a competitive advantage in the market.

Product opportunities can arise in a range of industries and can be based on new technology, changing consumer preferences or lifestyles, or emerging trends. Successful product opportunities are typically innovative, offer a unique value proposition, and have a clear target market.
product opportunity and license usage

A product opportunity can present a potential opportunity for a licensing agreement, as the licensor may have developed or discovered a new product or innovation, but may not have the resources or expertise to bring the product to market. In such a scenario, licensing the product to a licensee who has the necessary resources and expertise can be a mutually beneficial arrangement.

The licensor can earn revenue from the licensing agreement and the licensee can benefit from using the product or innovation without having to invest in product development or research. However, licensing agreements must be carefully negotiated and drafted to protect the rights and interests of both the licensor and the licensee.

License usage refers to the terms and conditions of how a licensee is allowed to use a licensed product or technology. These terms and conditions are typically outlined in the license agreement and may include restrictions on the scope of use, duration of use, and royalty or fee payments. License usage must comply with the terms and conditions outlined in the license agreement to avoid infringement of the licensor's intellectual property rights.
topic for product opportunity and license usage

One possible topic for product opportunity and license usage could be the development of a new software technology for a specific industry, such as healthcare or finance. The product opportunity could arise due to changes in regulations, advancements in technology, or unmet customer needs. Upon identifying this opportunity, a company may then seek to obtain a license to use technology or intellectual property from another company or individual, which can help speed up the product development process and bring the product to market quicker. However, the license usage must be carefully negotiated to protect the interests of both parties, with terms and conditions regarding usage, payments, and other obligations clearly defined in the license agreement.
Topic for product opportunity and license data

One possible topic for product opportunity and license data could be the development of a new information technology system for supply chain management. With the increasing demand for efficient and transparent supply chain systems, the opportunity arises to develop a new technology to meet these needs. This system can help track raw materials, inventory, and delivery schedules in real-time, streamline logistics, reduce waste, and increase efficiency.

However, developing this system may require the use of third-party data, such as tracking devices or software to collect and analyze supply chain data. In such cases, companies may seek a license to use this data, which can help speed up the product development process and improve the accuracy and efficiency of the final product.

The license agreement must be carefully drafted to define the scope of data usage, the terms of payment, and the responsibilities of the parties involved, while also ensuring that the use of third-party data does not infringe on existing intellectual property rights or violate any applicable laws and regulations.

翻译 重点内容
Key content
BFF 接口迁移
BFF接口迁移
翻译 BFF 接口迁移

BFF接口迁移

BFF（Backend for Frontend）是指为特定的前端应用程序设计的后端服务，它与前端应用程序紧密配合，提供定制化的API。当前，随着技术和业务的不断发展，需要对BFF接口进行迁移升级。这涉及到接口升级、版本管理、API文档更新等工作。迁移过程需要关注接口的稳定性、兼容性、可靠性，同时需要在保证正常运行基础上优化接口性能，规范接口访问。
翻译成英文：BFF 接口迁移
BFF Interface Migration
翻译成英文：IDL 生成 API 调用
IDL Generated API Invocation
BOE 环境 Mock
BOE Environment Mock
ToDev 管理平台
ToDev Management Platform
完成 Arena 与 Backstage 的 API 接口去 BFF 化，实现所有接口均收敛至网关，并最终下线 BFF 服务。
Complete the API interface BFF-ization for Arena and Backstage, and converge all interfaces to the gateway, finally going offline of the BFF service.
构建从 IDL 生成 API 调用的全链路解决方案，在基于服务端 IDL 生成前端的 API 调用代码之后（service.ts），前端的接口调用代码是具备 TS 全类型定义的，达成前端可以用类 RPC 调用的方式来请求后端接口的效果。

Build an end-to-end solution for generating API calls from IDL, after generating the frontend API call code based on the server-side IDL (service.ts), the frontend interface call code has TS full type definition, achieving the effect that the frontend can use the class RPC call to request the backend interface.
BOE 环境下许多页面的接口无数据，导致开发和调试困难，通过在 BOE 环境提供 Mock 解决方案，实现所有的无数据接口均能被 Mock 数据替代，让相关页面能在 BOE 环境下被正常访问。

Many pages' interfaces have no data in the BOE environment, making it difficult for development and debugging. By providing a Mock solution in the BOE environment, all interfaces without data can be replaced with Mock data, allowing relevant pages to be accessed normally in the BOE environment.
针对 RD 的内部提效场景，搭建 ToDev 的研发平台，将研发所需的相关功能（如接口管理、Mock、模块管理等）统一集成至平台上，完成 aPaaS 搭建的探索和集成、产出 ToDev 平台全栈开发最佳实践并形成研发侧的统一 Portal。
